hints_html:
The definition of the median is the number m such that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} = \int_{m}^{\infty}f(x)\,dx\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
The definition of the median is the number ''m'' such that

:<math> 
\frac{1}{2} = \int_{m}^{\infty}f(x)\,dx 
</math>
question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
As in the hint, we have that the median m is the number such that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} = \int_{m}^{\infty}f(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

We are told that m=10. Hence, evaluating this integral gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} &= \int_{10}^{\infty}ke^{-kx}\,dx \\ &= \lim_{c \to \infty}\int_{10}^{c}ke^{-kx}\,dx\\ &= \lim_{c \to \infty}-e^{-kx}\bigg|_{10}^{c}\\ &= \lim_{c \to \infty}-e^{-kc } + e^{-10k}\\ &= e^{-10k}\end{aligned}\]

Solving for k yields

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle e^{10k} = 2\end{aligned}\]

and thus

\[\begin{aligned} k = \frac{\ln(2)}{10}\end{aligned}\]

statement_html: An exponentially distributed continuous random variable X has probability density function \(f(x) = ke^{-kx}\) for \(x \geq 0\), where k is a positive constant. The median value of X equals 10. Find k.
statement_latex:
An exponentially distributed continuous random variable \emph{X} has
probability density function $f(x) = ke^{-kx}$ for $x \geq 0$, where
\emph{k} is a positive constant. The median value of \emph{X} equals 10.
Find \emph{k}.
